metadata.title: Tin/tin antimonide alloy nanoparticles embedded in electrospun porous carbon fibers as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries

sections.text:
Received: 21 December 2018
Accepted: 13 March 2019
Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer
Nature 2019
The pulverization of Sn-based electrode materials, caused by the large volume effect during the charging/discharging process, seriously affects their battery life. Compounding electrospun carbon fibers with a porous structure is an effective means of solving this problem. In this work, porous carbon nanofibers (PCNFs) containing Sn and tin antimonide (SnSb) alloy nanoparticles are prepared by electrospinning using self-made highly dispersed Sb–SnO2 (denoted as antimony-doped tin oxide) wet gel as the precursor of Sn and Sb and polyacrylonitrile (PAN) and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as the carbon sources. The porous structure is constructed using the difference in solubility in water between PAN and PVP. The results indicate that the as-fabricated PCNFs have a large number of pore structures and an even distribution of Sn and SnSb alloy nanoparticles, which are conducive to an increase in the content of Sn–SnSb electrode active materials. The porous structure both increases the specific surface area of the electrode material and effectively alleviates volume change. Therefore, the as-fabricated Sn–SnSb/PCNFs exhibit high specific capacities and outstanding rate performance and cycling retention, delivering specific capacities of 922 mAh g-1 and 266 mAh g at 50 mA g-1 and 5 A g-1, respectively, as well as a high cycle stability (71%) for 600 cycles at 1 A g-1. This demonstrates their potential application as anode materials in high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries.
Zhi Li and Qingfu Yin contributed equally to this work.
Address correspondence to E-mail: zhangjiwei@henu.edu.cn; jwzhang@henu.edu.cn
https://doi.org/10.1007/s10853-019-03539-z

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, with the widespread use and rapid development of portable electronic devices and electric vehicles, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have received extensive attention as the most commonly used energy storage systems. In particular, to meet the increasingly high power supply requirements of portable electronic devices and electric vehicles, the development of high-performance LIBs with high energy density, power density and endurance has become a research hotspot. Due to their low theoretical capacity (372 mAh/g), the graphite anode materials used in conventional commercial LIBs have gradually become one of the key factors limiting efforts to improve the electrochemical performance of LIBs. Recently, alloyed lithium-storage cathode materials (including silicon, germanium and tinbased cathode materials) with relatively high lithium storage capacity have become the most promising alternative to graphite anode materials. However, due to their enormous volume change during the electrochemical cycle and low intrinsic electron conductivity, these electrode materials undergo a serious volume effect, which causes them to pulverize and peel off from the current collector, resulting in a rapid decay in electrode capacity [1–3].
Two strategies can be adopted to solve the problem of volume expansion. The first is to nanocrystallize the electrode materials to minimize strain, and the second is to construct composite structures that combine active materials with a carbonaceous or metallic matrix. A carbonaceous matrix not only buffers volume change and reduces the stress concentration caused by lithium insertion [4–7], but also improves the conductivity between tin (Sn) nanoparticles and prevents the agglomeration of the electrode materials [8, 9]. A metallic matrix can also alleviate the expansion of Sn-based anode materials during electrochemical cycling; tin antimonide (SnSb) alloy compounds are considered to be the most promising candidate. First, as Sn and Sb differ in lithium insertion/extraction potential, the unreacted alloy phase can act as a buffer to alleviate volume expansion in the reaction phase, thereby improving the stability of the electrode materials [3, 10–13]; second, as Sn and Sb are electrochemically active, they both can contribute capacity to the electrode materials.
In recent years, electrospinning technology has become an important method of fabricating the micro-nanostructures of one-dimensional carbon fibers and nanoelectrode active materials [14, 15]. Electrospun carbon nanofibers (CNFs) can effectively relieve the volume expansion and contraction of electrode materials, prevent direct contact between the nanoparticle and electrolyte and stabilize the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film. The good conductivity of the carbon fibers provides a channel for the rapid transmission of electrons [16]. The combination of nanoporous structures with electrospun CNFs provides a highly developed internal surface area, realizing effective contact between the electrolyte and the electrode material and creating more open channels through which ions and electrons can rapidly migrate, resulting in excellent rate performance [17, 18]. For this purpose, polymers with different thermal stabilities can be blended to afford porous CNFs (PCNFs) and composite porous nanofibers by electrospinning [19]. Polymers with high thermal stability are carbonized to obtain CNFs, and polymers with lower thermal stability decompose to leave pore structures [20]. The difference in compatibility (or solubility) between polymers can also be utilized in the preparation of PCNFs; the lower the compatibility (or solubility) of polymers, the larger the pore size formed [21].
In a previous work, we used a Sb–SnO2 (denoted as antimony-doped tin oxide, ATO) wet gel as a Sn and SnSb precursor for electrospinning [22]. Using this special precursor solved the problems of the dispersion of nanoparticle precursors in polymers and the precipitation of metal salt precursors on the fiber surface; the composites exhibited excellent cycling performance and rate performance.
In this study, a composite of Sn–SnSb nanoparticles and porous carbon nanofibers was prepared by electrospinning, using ATO wet gel as the Sn–SnSb nanoparticle precursor and polyacrylonitrile (PAN) and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as the carbon sources. The Sn–SnSb nanoparticles were found to exhibit a homogeneous distribution in PCNFs without precipitation on the fiber surface. The high content of Sn–SnSb and large specific surface area gave the hybrid nanocomposites a very high capacity and good rate capability, suggesting their potential application as an anode material in high-energydensity LIBs.

sections.heading: Fabrication of Sn–SnSb/PCNFs
sections.text: The experimental procedure for fabricating Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs by electrospinning was shown in Scheme 1. A 0.3 g sample of wet ATO precursor slurry (with ATO prepared as reported elsewhere [22]) was dispersed in 20 mL of dimethylformamide/tetrahydrofuran solvent (volume ratio 3:1) and sonicated for 30 min. Next, 2 g of PVP and 1 g of PAN were added to the ATO precursor solution under continuous stirring at 60 C to obtain a homogeneous solution. The resulting ATO/PAN/PVP precursor solution was taken a 5-mL disposable syringe, and electrospinning was carried out using a 21-gauge stainless steel needle with a positive voltage of 15 kV and a negative voltage of 3 kV. The distance from the needle to the collection end was 20 cm, giving an extrusion rate of 0.25 mm/min. The electrospun PAN/PVP/ATO nanofibers obtained were first hydrothermally treated at 100 C for 24 h to remove the PVP. The resultant composite nanofibers were then dried at 60 C and pre-oxidized at 150 C for 24 h and 280 C for 2 h in air. Finally, they were carbonized at 700 C for 1 h in an argon (Ar) gas atmosphere to afford Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs. For comparison, Sn–SnSb/CNFs without a porous carbon structure were prepared in the same manner but with no hydrothermal treatment.

sections.heading: Characterization
sections.text:
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JSM-2010, JEOL Ltd.) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Nova Nano SEM 450, FEI Company) images were used to observe the morphology of the prepared nanofibers. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8 with Cu-Ka radiation at a
wavelength of 0.15406 nm. Nitrogen adsorption was measured with surface area equipment (SI-MP-20, Quantachrome Instruments).

sections.heading: Electrochemical performance evaluation
sections.text: To evaluate the electrochemical performance, the prepared Sn–SnSb/PCNFs were first homogeneously mixed with a conductive reagent (acetylene black) and binder (carboxymethyl cellulose) at a mass ratio of 8:1:1. A few drops of distilled water were added to form a uniform slurry, and the result was coated on the copper foil uniformly and dried in a vacuum at 100 C for 8 h. The copper foil coated with active materials was cut into thin sheets (15 mm diameter) to give the working electrode, and Li foil was used as the counter electrode, with 2016 coin-type half cells assembled in an Ar-filled glove box (water and oxygen content lower than 1 ppm). A 1 M LiPF6 solution was used as the electrolyte, with ethylene carbonate and dimethyl carbonate at a volume ratio of 1:1 as a mixed solvent. The separator was a polypropylene microporous membrane (Celgard 2400). The charging/discharging test was carried out using a LANDCT2001A battery test system with a cut-off voltage of 0.01–3 V (vs. Li/Li?) at 25 C. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) curves were obtained using a Zahner IM6e. The results of the CV (0.0–3.0 V) test were recorded at a scan rate of 0.05 mV s-1, and the EIS test was conducted using an alternating current of 5 mV in a frequency range from 10-2 to 102 kHz.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
In the XRD patterns of the Sn–SnSb/CNFs and Sn– SnSb/PCNFs samples in Fig. 1, all of the diffraction
Scheme 1 Schematic illustration for fabricating Sn–SnSb/PCNFs by electrospinning.
peaks are well indexed to the tetragonal Sn (JCPDS: 04-0673) and SnSb (JCPDS: 33-0018). This implies that after carbonization at an elevated temperature, the ATO nanoparticles were mainly transformed into Sn in association with a small amount of SnSb alloys, due to the reducibility of carbon at 700 C. The grain sizes of the Sn nanoparticles in the Sn–SnSb/CNFs and Sn–SnSb/PCNFs were about 26 and 40 nm, respectively, calculated using Scherrer’s equation based on the (200) crystal plane of the tetragonal Sn.
Figure 2 exhibits the SEM images of the Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs and Sn–SnSb/CNFs. It shows that the diameter of the Sn–SnSb/CNFswas approximately 450 nm. The fibers became uneven and exhibited an increased average diameter of about 510 nm after the removal of PVP.Thismayhavebeendue to the swellingof residual PVP and the formation of pores after PVP removal.
Comparison of the TEM images (Fig. 3) of the Sn– SnSb/PCNFs and Sn–SnSb/CNFs revealed a large
number of pore structures in the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs, whereas the Sn–SnSb/CNFs did not have a porous structure. The Sn and SnSb nanoparticles in the Sn– SnSb/PCNFs were larger than those in the Sn–SnSb/ CNFs, and the surface of the composite Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs fibers was uneven, consistent with the results of SEM and XRD. This may be due to the low melting point (231.89 C) of Sn, which made it feasible for Sn nanoparticles to grow during calcination at an elevated temperature. The uniformly distributed holes in the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs were favorable for the growth of Sn nanoparticles during heat treatment, whereas the density of the Sn–SnSb/CNFs may have limited the growth of Sn nanoparticles.
The porous structure and specific surface area of the Sn–SnSb/CNFs and Sn–SnSb/PCNFs were determined through nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurements. As shown in Fig. 4, the Sn–SnSb/ CNFs exhibited type II isotherms, whereas the Sn– SnSb/PCNFs samples presented type IV isotherms, indicating that the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs sample maintained a mesoporous structure. The average pore size of the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs was 3.816 nm (inset in Fig. 4). After introducing the porous structure, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller specific surface area of the Sn– SnSb/PCNFs and Sn–SnSb/CNFs was 140 m2g-1 and 36 m2g-1, respectively, representing a nearly fourfold increase. This increase in specific surface area can be ascribed to the porous structure formed in the Sn– SnSb/PCNFs compared with the dense and poreless structure of the Sn–SnSb/CNFs sample. The voids around the nanoparticles in Sn–SnSb/PCNFs provided a buffer space for the change in volume of Sn– SnSb nanoparticles during the charging/discharging process. The increase in the specific surface area of
Sn–SnSb/PCNFs also promoted contact between theFigure 1 XRD patterns of Sn–SnSb/CNFs and Sn–SnSb/PCNFs.
electrolyte and the electrode material and shortened the transmission distance between the electrons and lithium ions (Li ions). As a result, the Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs exhibited excellent electrochemical performance.
Figure 5a shows the CV curves for the Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs electrode. The two reduction peaks at about 0.60 and 0.78 V resulted from the generation of LixSb alloys due to the lithiation of Sb. The reduction peak at 0.33 V (vs. Li/Li?) was due to the alloying reaction of Sn and Li. The oxidation peaks at 0.5–0.8 V were caused by the dealloying of the LixSn alloys, and the oxidation peak near 1.17 V was attributable to the delithiation process of LixSb [10, 11, 23–25]. The nearoverlap of the curves for the second and third cycles indicates the excellent electrochemical reversibility and structural stability of the electrode materials.
Figure 5b exhibits the charge/discharge voltage profiles of the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs electrode at current densities ranging from 0.05 A g-1 to 5 A g-1. The voltage gradually declined from around 0.6–0.8 V and below 0.5 V in the first discharge stage, and a voltage plateau arose at around 0.5–0.8 V in the charge stage, consistent with the CV characterization (Fig. 5a). The first discharge capacities and charge capacities were 1286 mAh g and 1000 mAh g, respectively, and the coulombic efficiency of the first charge/discharge at 0.05 A g-1 was 77.8%. The
capacity loss (about 286 mAh g) was mainly due to the irreversible reaction caused by the formation of SEI film [26].
The rate capacities of the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs and Sn– SnSb/CNFs are shown in Fig. 6a. The Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs electrode delivered higher capacities than the Sn–SnSb/CNFs electrode. The Sn–SnSb/PCNFs electrode exhibited discharge capacities of 922, 823, 737 and 632 mAh g at low current densities (0.05, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.5 A g-1, respectively) and retained capacities of 546, 433, 353 and 266 mAh g at higher current densities (1, 2, 3 and 5 A g-1, respectively), showing high reversible capacity and good rate performance. There are two reasons for this improvement in electrochemical performance: first, the content of Sn and SnSb increased due to the reduction in the carbon component; second, and more importantly, the addition of the porous structure increased the specific surface area of the electrode material, promoting contact between the electrode material and electrolyte and enhancing the material’s electron and Li-ion transport ability, thereby improving its electrochemical performance. The capacity retention rates of the Sn–SnSb/CNFs and Sn–SnSb/PCNFs, based on the discharge capacity of 0.05 A g-1, are shown in
Fig. 6b. The capacity retention rate of the Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs was much higher than that of the non-porous SnSb/CNFs, consistent with the better rate performance of the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs. The cyclic stability of the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs electrode is shown in Fig. 6c. After 600 cycles, the specific capacity was 447 mAh g at 1 A g-1 and the corresponding capacity retention rate was 72%, showing excellent cyclic stability, and columbic efficiency was maintained at 100% across
the 600 cycles, resulting in ideal reversible lithium intercalation.
EIS was used to investigate the electron and Li-ion transport kinetics. Figure 7 shows the impedance curves and the corresponding equivalent circuits of the Sn–SnSb/CNFs and Sn–SnSb/PCNFs electrodes. Both curves show a semicircle and an inclined line. Based on the equivalent circuit in the inset of v 7, the
fitting results reveal that R0 and Rct were 1.7 X and 185.4 X for the Sn–SnSb/CNFs and 1.3 X and 96.5 X for the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs, respectively, indicating fast electrochemical reaction kinetics in the Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs electrode [27].
In situ XRD was applied to explore the crystal structural evolution of the Sn–SnSb/PCNFs electrode during the charging/discharging process. In the in situ XRD patterns shown in Fig. 8, the peaks characteristic of SnSb (2h = 29.1 ) and Sn (2h = 30.6 and 32.0 ) fade away in the first discharge stage. A new peak emerges at 2h = 25 , corresponding to the formation of LixSb and LixSn. Notably, the peaks characteristic of SnSb and Sn repeat during the next iterative charge process, indicating that the composite Sn–SnSb/PCNFs electrode had high structural stability and high reversibility during repeated charging and discharging.
To evaluate the structural stability of the Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs electrode material after repeated charge and discharge cycles, morphological investigations were conducted before and after 600 cycles at a charge/ discharge current density of 1 A g-1. As shown in Fig. 9, the membrane on the electrode surface was largely intact, despite some ruptures, after 600 dis-
charge/charge cycles (Fig. 9b). The state of the
membrane before the cycles is shown in Fig. 9a. Notably, the fiber structure was well maintained (Fig. 9c) because the porous structure inside the fiber alleviated volume expansion and contraction and thereby enhanced the overall structural stability during the charge/discharge process.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: Sn–SnSb/PCNFs were fabricated by electrospinning with a blend of PAN/PVP. Based on differences in the solubility of the polymers, the carbon content was reduced and a porous structure was introduced. Compared with the Sn–SnSb/CNFs, the Sn–SnSb/ PCNFs exhibited better electrochemical performance and thus greater potential as anode materials for LIBs, as they had a larger specific surface area due to their porous structure and a greater content of Sn alloy nanoparticles. These findings have practical implications for the fabrication of PCNF/nanoparticle composites for LIBs.

sections.text: The authors acknowledge funding from the Natural Science Foundation of Henan Province (162300410023) and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 21671057, 21271063, U1704253).
